discourse_list.title: How does Makers emergency shutdown work exactly? How are liveness failures prevented?

content.content: I understand that in an emergency scenario, MKR holders can send tokens to an emergency shutdown module to initiate a protocol shutdown once a threshold of tokens are met. My question is, is this module contract publicly viewable? If so, how does Maker prevent spam attacks where malicious actors send tokens to the address to initiate a shutdown even though there was no emergency scenario?

K1872:  is this module contract publicly viewable?   Yes - esm.sol.     K1872:  how does Maker prevent spam attacks where malicious actors send tokens to the address to initiate a shutdown even though there was no emergency scenario?   Because MKR tokens sent to the ESM are burned, this disincentivizes people from spamming the module as they lose their tokens. Maker Governance, therefore, needs to strike a balance between making the ESM prohibitively expensive for a malicious actor to abuse as well as achievable to trigger in a true emergency scenario. Note the current status of the ESM is visible here. It’s also worth pointing out that when ESM is triggered and MCD is shut down, nothing is stopping MKR holders whose tokens have not been burned from voting to start a new version of the system.
this makes perfect sense. thank you for clarifying!
